tit.e: Ometsuke (a governmental post in the Edo period)
tit.cmt: 用語統一に合わせました。

sen.j: 大目付（おおめつけ）は、江戸幕府の役職のひとつで、職制上は老中に属し、大名・高家および朝廷を監視してこれらの謀反から幕府を守る監察官の役割を持った。
sen.e: Ometsuke was a governmental post in the Edo period, and belonging to Roju (the second highest post in the Edo bakufu government) in the government system, played the role of an inspector who watched daimyo (Japanese feudal lord), koke (privileged families under Tokugawa Shogunate), and the Imperial court to protect the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) from rebellion of these powers.

sen.j: 江戸時代初期には、柳生宗矩のような大名からも選ばれていたが、後に石高3千石〜5千石級の旗本から選ばれた。
sen.e: In the early Edo period, an Ometsuke officer was selected from daimyo, as Munenori YAGYU was, but later, from Hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu, which was a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) earning a rice crop of 3000 to 5000 koku (approx. 180 liters/koku).

sen.j: 大目付は、旗本の職の中でも江戸城留守居・御三卿家老に準ずる最高位とされた。
sen.e: Ometuse was one of the highest post available for Hatamoto, being equivalent to Edojo-rusui (the post of housekeeping the Edo castle while the shogun was absent from the castle) and the Karo (the chief retainer) post at the gosankyo families (three privileged branch families of Tokugawa).
